keyMetrics: 200% increase in coding efficiency and productivity at Memorial Hermann Hospital
2 months to an evolved prototype used by client and customer
$4B in revenues handled by the software
30 minutes to diagnose incident (no patients left to code)
Coders use the software 6 days a week, 9-to-5
technologies: NLP algorithm for evidence extraction in documents
Rapid prototyping with real-time user feedback
deliverables: Unified user experience for hospital coding
Comprehensive coding service with built-in automation
3m-coderyte.problemStatement: CodeRyte’s hospital coding product was perceived as a bolt-on tool; they needed to transform it into a complete end-to-end coding system to dominate the market while contending with legacy systems and compliance requirements.
3m-coderyte.solutionStatement: GoInvo delivered an 8-week POC followed by a 12-week working web-based prototype, designing a unified UX with built-in automation powered by CodeRyte’s NLP and iterating rapidly with real user feedback from Memorial Hermann.
3m-coderyte.businessValue: Achieved a 200% efficiency gain at Memorial Hermann and culminated in a $146MM acquisition by 3M.
3m-coderyte.targetUsers: Hospital medical coders and coding teams responsible for tagging patient records for insurance reimbursement.

keyMetrics: Monthly workgroup meetings with 30 subject matter experts
Initial release: 1 publisher and 6 cardiovascular CDS tools
By Nov 2018: 7 publishers and more than 25 CDS tools
deliverables: Introductory onboarding pages with step-by-step visualizations
Human-readable clinical logic and evidence display
ahrq-cds.problemStatement: Clinicians lacked a common platform to share clinical decision support (CDS) tools, leading to inconsistent adherence to evidence-based standards and redundant tool development.
ahrq-cds.solutionStatement: Designed CDS Connect, an AHRQ-funded national repository for providers, health IT vendors, and researchers to create, share, and explore CDS tools with transparent evidence and implementation-readiness information.
ahrq-cds.businessValue: Delivered a national CDS repository that launched in Sept 2017 and grew from 1 publisher with 6 tools to 7 publishers and 25+ tools across multiple clinical domains by Nov 2018.
ahrq-cds.targetUsers: Providers, health IT vendors, researchers, clinicians, and implementers in health organizations.

keyMetrics: 90% of the U.S. patient population aren’t involved in research
Launching a new activity can take several months to a year or more
technologies: Design system and reusable UI components
deliverables: Participant portal UX and designs (All of Us PTSC)
Design library with reusable UI components and style guides
Open illustration library and program-wide visual guidelines
Content and design guidelines for returns of results
Portal redesign with updated information architecture
Roadmap for new features and prioritization
all-of-us.problemStatement: Medical research participation lacks diversity, with 90% of U.S. patients not involved. The All of Us program needed participant-focused digital experiences to enroll and retain enough participants to reach its 1 million goal.
all-of-us.solutionStatement: From 2020–2024, GoInvo led product design for the All of Us Participant Portal within PTSC under Vibrent Health, creating onboarding, consent, survey, and returns-of-results experiences and establishing program-wide design systems and guidelines.
all-of-us.businessValue: Program-wide UX and design assets helped the program reach 700,000+ enrolled participants (impacting 750k registered participants) and create accessible pathways for more people to join.
all-of-us.targetUsers: U.S. participants in the NIH All of Us Research Program—including those underrepresented in biomedical research—who use the portal to enroll, consent, contribute data, and view results.

keyMetrics: An estimated 7,000 Care Cards decks in circulation
deliverables: Written insights and tips on card backs
care-cards.problemStatement: Improving and maintaining health is difficult; available advice is far-flung and temporal, and clinician guidance often fades after the visit.
care-cards.solutionStatement: A pocket-sized deck of 54 illustrated Care Cards delivers practical health axioms with concise tips to nudge everyday, sustainable habits.
care-cards.businessValue: Gained broad adoption with ~7,000 decks used in homes, clinics, and classes, featured by NPR and presented by leaders including Susannah Fox (CTO of HHS), Eric Topol, and Claudia Williams.
care-cards.targetUsers: Patients, clinicians, healthcare organizations, and everyday people using the cards in homes, clinics, and classes.

keyMetrics: Two to six week project bursts
deliverables: Designs and prototypes for informed patient data sharing
UI/UX design review of the CommonHealth app
Research and design concepts for presenting clinical notes and insurance data via FHIR R4
Groundwork designs for verifiable vaccination records and test results
SMART Health Cards UI workflow and key screens
Patient education content and FAQs for SMART Health Cards
SMART Health Cards walkthrough published on the CommonHealth website
commonhealth-smart-health-cards.problemStatement: The Commons Project needed an infusion of design across their product and services to explore and define the future of patient data access and use.
commonhealth-smart-health-cards.solutionStatement: The team embedded via a flexible project model to deliver research, concepting, prototyping, user testing, iteration, and documentation across patient data sharing, app design review, FHIR R4 data presentation, and verifiable vaccination records, contributing feedback and designs to the SMART Health Cards initiative.
commonhealth-smart-health-cards.businessValue: Positioned CommonHealth as the primary Android open source platform and reference implementation for accessing and storing digital vaccine records and adding them to Google or Samsung Wallet, contributing to SMART Health Cards’ global adoption.
commonhealth-smart-health-cards.targetUsers: Patients using the CommonHealth Android app to gather, store, and share their health data and verifiable vaccination/test result records.

keyMetrics: 12% of US adults are health literate
41% of individuals have accessed their medical record
29 of 30 patients correctly identified the five factors of health data
90% of patients engaged with an online quiz
Year-long engagement with an advisory panel
deliverables: Two open source educational plug-in prototypes
Health data definition grounded in determinants of health
fastercures-health-data-basics.problemStatement: Most patients lack the health literacy and access needed to understand and use their health data (only 12% health literate; 41% have accessed their medical record). FasterCures needed a way to educate and engage patients on what health data is and why it matters.
fastercures-health-data-basics.solutionStatement: GoInvo created two open source educational plug-in prototypes for web and mobile, leveraging gamification and behavior change models (HBM) to teach the factors of health data. The prototypes use interactive quizzes and targeted messaging to improve comprehension and engagement.
fastercures-health-data-basics.businessValue: The open source assets effectively educated patients (29/30 recalled key factors; 90% engaged with the quiz) and can be reused across services to scale health data education.
fastercures-health-data-basics.targetUsers: Patients and caretakers using web or mobile health services to learn about and engage with their health data.

keyMetrics: Healthcare data expected to grow 1.2–2.4 exabytes per year
About 1,000x the amount of data the human brain can store
Potential cost reduction from early adoption of tools like hGraph: $160–220 billion
Savings from disease prevention/data adherence: $70–100 billion
Savings from coordinated care programs: $90–110 billion
37% of companies (>5,000 employees) offer on-site health clinics
15% plan to add on-site clinics within two years
62% cite enhanced worker productivity as top reason for onsite clinics
56% cite reduced medical costs as second reason
Estimated annual US deaths due to medical errors: 251,454 (2016)
hgraph.problemStatement: Healthcare data is exploding (1.2–2.4 exabytes/year) and is big, disparate, and unstructured, making it difficult for patients and providers to identify useful information. Patients and healthcare providers need analytic tools that collect data and make sense of it.
hgraph.solutionStatement: hGraph aggregates and visualizes a patient's health data in a compact, color-coded shape that compares metrics to targeted ranges and highlights out-of-range values. It provides at-a-glance context, including an overall hScore (1–100), to help clinicians swiftly spot problem areas.
hgraph.businessValue: McKinsey estimates early adoption of tools like hGraph could reduce U.S. healthcare costs by $160–220 billion.
hgraph.targetUsers: Clinicians/medical professionals and patients; also used in corporate/onsite health clinics.

technologies: Use of color in real-time charts
Timeline visualization of cardiac events, heart rate, and physical activity
Machine- and patient-detected arrhythmia indicators with metadata
deliverables: Individual patient timeline view (events, heart rate, physical activity)
infobionic-heart-monitoring.problemStatement: InfoBionic built a patient‑worn device that reports arrhythmias in real time but needed a compelling way to demonstrate the product to doctors and investors.
infobionic-heart-monitoring.solutionStatement: GoInvo crafted an iPad application that visualizes real-time arrhythmia data so providers and investors could see how the product would be used in practice.
infobionic-heart-monitoring.businessValue: The design led to a patent on ECG data processing/display, received FDA approval and CE Mark for arrhythmia monitoring, and helped InfoBionic close $17M in Series B financing.
infobionic-heart-monitoring.targetUsers: Doctors and nurses who remotely monitor patients’ arrhythmias.

keyMetrics: 10 years live in use for bioassay results visualization
deliverables: Return-of-information service for blood work and nutrition profile
Nutrition decision support service feeding suggestions from the InsideTracker science team to the patient food recommendation service
Software model for behavior and precision nutrition
Early mobile UX concepts for a nutrition agent/activity model
insidetracker-nutrition-science.problemStatement: InsideTracker needed to clearly present patients’ bioassay information and resulting nutrition needs, and help them choose the right foods at the right time to improve health outcomes.
insidetracker-nutrition-science.solutionStatement: Designed an easy-to-read return-of-information experience that visualizes bioassay results and personalized food suggestions across first and subsequent blood draws. Delivered a nutrition decision support service that channels science team guidance into the patient food recommendation service.
insidetracker-nutrition-science.businessValue: Delivered a long-lived patient results visualization and the first nutrition decision support service, plus concepts that fed product and development teams’ next software iteration around goals and daily habits.
insidetracker-nutrition-science.targetUsers: InsideTracker patients seeking personalized nutrition guidance based on their blood work, DNA, habits, and lifestyle.

deliverables: Open source web-based e-book (Inspired EHRs: Designing for Clinicians)
Lightweight design policy for electronic health records
Interactive prototypes and example EHR components embedded in chapters
Medication timeline and medication list designs
inspired-ehrs.problemStatement: Current EHRs have clumsy interfaces, poorly designed information, and cumbersome workflows that distance clinicians from quality care, contributing to clinician burnout and patient risk.
inspired-ehrs.solutionStatement: A team of physicians, nurses, health IT, and HCI experts co-authored and designed an open-source, HTML-based e-book with interactive prototypes to distribute evidence-based designs and techniques to EHR vendors.
inspired-ehrs.businessValue: Provided an open-source, accessible, lightweight design policy to jumpstart EHR design on a national level.
inspired-ehrs.targetUsers: Health IT and EHR vendors, along with designers and engineers building EHR systems.

keyMetrics: 75% of employees across 86 countries certified in Generative AI
Insights delivered in hours instead of weeks
3 months to move from vendor to core contributor
technologies: Chat-based interface integrated with tools and templates
deliverables: Report wizard to convert insights into a client-ready deliverable
Ipsos Facto UX design for the research agent experience
ipsos-facto.problemStatement: The initial Ipsos Facto release was a basic generative-AI chatbot that lacked the UX and research-specific scaffolding needed for analytical work, with siloed chat/files/tools and no clear path from insight to action. These gaps led to low adoption and dissatisfaction with AI results.
ipsos-facto.solutionStatement: GoInvo collaborated with Ipsos to rebuild Facto’s research agent experience with guided workflows, research-specific tools (content curation, meta-analysis, transcript coding), embedded prompts, and transparent AI logic, integrating chat with templates and tools. This enables analysis of 40+ years of proprietary data and delivery of cited, client-ready insights in hours instead of weeks.
ipsos-facto.businessValue: Drove 90%+ adoption and 700,000+ prompts per month (10M+ API calls), moving Facto from internal experiment to client-ready product and increasing revenue potential.
ipsos-facto.targetUsers: Ipsos market researchers, with client teams served via client-facing AI agents.

keyMetrics: 1 in 10 MA households are food insecure
$15–$352 per month for a family of two in SNAP benefits
$1 in new SNAP benefits generates $1.80 in total economic activity
Reduced questions from about 90 to 40 for a two-person household
67% smartphone ownership among Americans earning under $30,000/year
Deployed July 2018; online applications exceeded in-person for the first time at MA DTA
mass-snap.problemStatement: The SNAP application process in Massachusetts was grueling and intimidating, with a two-person family facing about 90 questions just to get past the first step, hindering access to food assistance.
mass-snap.solutionStatement: Redesigned the online application to be mobile-first, accessible (WCAG/508), multilingual, and streamlined, using conditional logic to remove irrelevant questions and reduce the burden from about 90 to 40 questions. Built a React reference implementation and front-end components used in production.
mass-snap.businessValue: Drove a 50% increase in digital applications, and after the July 2018 launch, online applications surpassed in-person submissions at MA DTA for the first time.
mass-snap.targetUsers: Massachusetts residents applying for SNAP benefits through the DTA’s online application.

keyMetrics: 20% projected employment growth in home healthcare over the next decade
Scheduling scale requirement: 50 nurses and 1,000 patient visits
deliverables: Clinical note and assessment interface mockup
maya-ehr.problemStatement: Home health agencies lack affordable EHRs tailored to field nursing and administrative needs; larger EHRs are expensive and don’t adequately support nurses in the field or at home.
maya-ehr.solutionStatement: Designed and shipped a clinically relevant, rules-compliant EHR that is straightforward to use on the go and in the office, with end-to-end workflows for intake, scheduling, care, and administration.
maya-ehr.businessValue: Delivered a deployed EHR with essential scheduling, documentation, and administrative capabilities that supports efficient patient management in home healthcare settings.
maya-ehr.targetUsers: Home health agency staff, including nurses/practitioners in the field and back-office/scheduling teams.

keyMetrics: 97% of cancer patients have fractured, uncoordinated, poor-quality data
Shadowed 4 oncologists at Dana Farber Cancer Institute
Weekly feedback with 1–3 physicians, 2 key engineers, and a patient advocate
User testing planned for mid-2018 at Brigham and Women’s Hospital
Secured an additional year of funding for the SHR initiative
technologies: Hashtag-based data capture in clinical notes
deliverables: Prototype for interrogating the Standard Health Record (SHR)
Structured data capture interface (UI and hashtag input)
mitre-flux-notes.problemStatement: Oncology providers rarely capture high-quality, standardized data, resulting in 97% of cancer patients having fractured, uncoordinated, poor-quality records that hinder care and research.
mitre-flux-notes.solutionStatement: Designed Flux Notes, a web application built on the oncology subset of the Standard Health Record (SHR), to capture structured data at the point of care via hashtag-enhanced note authoring and a simplified, personalized interface.
mitre-flux-notes.businessValue: Flux Notes helped secure an additional year of funding for the SHR initiative by demonstrating a clinical prototype using SHR.
mitre-flux-notes.targetUsers: Oncologists and providers documenting patient encounters at the point of care.

keyMetrics: $80 billion annual cost to the US healthcare system from lack of a health data standard
2018: SHR accepted into the international HL7 FHIR standard as an oncology profile
October 2016: State-level support from the Governor of Massachusetts
deliverables: System diagrams of the SHR ecosystem
Graphic visual language for the SHR
Design concepts and SHR use cases
Flux Notes oncology data curation interface
mitre-shr.problemStatement: The U.S. lacked a national health data standard, preventing efficient sharing and management of health data and costing the system $80B annually. MITRE needed a vision for SHR’s technical architecture and the services that could be built on it to drive development and policy.
mitre-shr.solutionStatement: GoInvo analyzed interoperability pain points and, collaborating with 20+ MITRE engineers and clinicians, produced system diagrams, a visual language, prototypes, and storyboards to clearly represent SHR and showcase SHR-enabled services.
mitre-shr.businessValue: The work contributed to SHR’s acceptance into the HL7 FHIR standard (2018) and led to hospital partnerships (Dana-Farber Cancer Institute and Brigham and Women’s Hospital) for real-world testing.
mitre-shr.targetUsers: Healthcare providers and hospital systems, MITRE engineers and clinicians, policymakers, and patients engaging with SHR-enabled personal and remote care tools.

deliverables: Open source touchscreen service for public health information and stories
mitre-state-of-us-healthcare.problemStatement: US healthcare issues and statistics are difficult to understand and visualize, even in data-rich environments. MITRE Health Lab needed a national-scale storytelling service to convey ground truth to public health officials, researchers, and policy makers.
mitre-state-of-us-healthcare.solutionStatement: Built an interactive healthcare story engine and a custom browser-based experience that spans a 12-panel touchscreen wall using open web standards and Chrome. The experience was designed to showcase research and stories in the context of national problem sets and was released as open source.
mitre-state-of-us-healthcare.businessValue: Open-sourcing the US Healthcare Dashboard enables government agencies and healthcare companies to use, update, and evolve interactive public health stories at lower cost and effort.
mitre-state-of-us-healthcare.targetUsers: Public health officials, researchers, policy makers, and scientists in the MITRE HealthLab and other government/healthcare organizations.

keyMetrics: 600,000+ individuals collected for The Resilience Project
1,000,000 entire human genomes target for The Resilience Project
77% of adults in the US have smartphones
technologies: Emotion and heart rate response detection
deliverables: Result report for The Resilience Project
Electronic consent workflow for The Resilience Project
System model of the Consent-as-a-Service (CaaS) software
Genetic report designs for IVF patients
mount-sinai-consent.problemStatement: Paper-based consent was cumbersome, labor-intensive, unscalable, non-transferable, and frequently abandoned by patients and staff.
mount-sinai-consent.solutionStatement: Built a cloud-based, open-source SaaS e-consent service enabling patients to digitally consent and share data, with a mobile experience featuring interactive lessons, VUI, voice signatures, and adaptive content informed by real-time expression comprehension.
mount-sinai-consent.businessValue: Replaced paper consent with a scalable digital workflow that enabled large-scale participant recruitment, contributing to over 600,000 individuals for The Resilience Project.
mount-sinai-consent.targetUsers: Patients (including IVF patients) enrolling in genomics studies, and clinicians, nurses, administrators, doctors, and proxies who manage consent and interpret genetic results.

deliverables: Human body pain map interface (shades of red by location and severity)
Early concept for tracking pain and intensity
paintrackr.problemStatement: Pain measurement is dominated by a simplistic 1–5 illustrated face scale, and there is no open-source human body model to pinpoint complaints. Pain is nuanced and requires more nuanced recording and measurement.
paintrackr.solutionStatement: Designed and built PainTrackr, an open-source app that lets patients log pain by severity and location on a human body map and share their pain history with their PCP.
paintrackr.businessValue: Enables easier digital pain logging and sharing to improve patient–provider communication and replace pen-and-paper tracking.
paintrackr.targetUsers: Patients who need to track physical pain and primary care providers who receive the shared pain history.

keyMetrics: more than two dozen key stakeholders
partners-geneinsight.problemStatement: Partners Healthcare needed to move GeneInsight out of a closed lab and make it commercially available to clinicians, but genomic data is difficult to interpret even for specialists.
partners-geneinsight.solutionStatement: GoInvo redesigned GeneInsight to let clinicians connect with labs, perform genetic analysis, receive clear, patient-specific reports, and get ongoing updates on detected variants; report drafting was streamlined via a template builder to reduce clicks and information overload.
partners-geneinsight.businessValue: Partners Healthcare launched the GeneInsight Suite as commercial-grade software used across multiple hospital systems in the United States.
partners-geneinsight.targetUsers: Clinicians, geneticists, laboratory technicians, genetic research scientists, and clinical specialists who create, access, and review patient-specific genetic reports.

keyMetrics: 6 major research institutions served by the portal
deliverables: Redesigned workflows for the Humans module
Redesigned protocol list grouped by study with status indicators
Navigable submission forms with clear language and contextual help
Transparent status and play-by-play history views
Version history and change tracking views
Inventory of screens and catalog of base components and reusable styles
Consultation on front-end engineering, UAT, and QA
partners-insight.problemStatement: Insight, the PHRC electronic IRB portal used across six major research institutions, had serious usability issues that impeded turnaround times and delayed research for weeks.
partners-insight.solutionStatement: The team redesigned the most complex module (Humans) to create a more efficient workflow using usability best practices and guided experiences, added clear status and history, navigable forms with contextual help, inline comments, and versioning, and established a foundational design system for the broader application.
partners-insight.businessValue: Improved approval turnaround rates and reduced time to prepare, submit, and review protocols, with Insight 4.0 rolling out to all Partners research facilities.
partners-insight.targetUsers: IRB reviewers and research teams at Partners-affiliated institutions, including analysts, admins, program chairs, principal investigators, and support staff.

technologies: Parallel strategy design (recruitment, data collection, member retention)
deliverables: Refocused mission and restructuring for PGP
Creation of new partner organization: OpenHumans
Concept for OpenHumans web portal for members
personal-genome-project-vision.problemStatement: The Personal Genome Project sought to sequence 100,000 genomes but lacked a clear, shared path among founders to realize the vision.
personal-genome-project-vision.solutionStatement: GoInvo led a one-day exploratory workshop, mapping the existing ecosystem and using live sketching to identify pain points, leading to a reimagined organizational model separating recruitment, data collection, and member retention.
personal-genome-project-vision.businessValue: The effort produced a refocused mission, organizational restructuring, and the creation of OpenHumans to better engage members and enable researcher access.
personal-genome-project-vision.targetUsers: PGP members who donate and manage their data via OpenHumans, and researchers (academic, independent, and citizen scientists) accessing genomes and medical histories through a separate interface.

keyMetrics: Treatment delays up to two weeks
technologies: Information extraction from unstructured clinical reports
deliverables: Reviewer interface with flexible panels and clear information hierarchy
Organized case queue with periodic refresh and cross-access
NLP model to classify patient documents and extract structured data
Patient record view with timeline visualization
Protocol review drawer and actions panel (approve/adjust/deny)
Note capture widget/panel with reliable saving
prior-auth.problemStatement: Prior authorization for cancer care is lengthy and complex, causing treatment delays of up to two weeks and placing heavy administrative burden on providers, insurers, and reviewers.
prior-auth.solutionStatement: Designed reviewer-focused tools that use NLP to extract structured data from unstructured records, reorganize information with a clear hierarchy and flexible panels, improve queues and note-taking, and automate straightforward determinations based on rules and guidelines.
prior-auth.businessValue: Reduced wait times and administrative effort, enabling faster approvals and earlier treatment while saving time and money for providers, hospitals, and insurers.
prior-auth.targetUsers: Clinical and prescribing experts who review prior authorization cases for insurers and specialized processing organizations; secondary users include provider administrative staff.

keyMetrics: Every $1 invested in design results in government savings
deliverables: Redesigned Mass SNAP application interface (digitized application process)
Future-state journey map for CMS's Medicaid Marketplace
Designs for SMART Health Cards for the CommonHealth application
public-sector.problemStatement: Government services, including the Massachusetts SNAP application, were burdened by outdated, complex processes that were hard to navigate for diverse users, while being constrained by rigid policy and regulatory requirements.
public-sector.solutionStatement: GoInvo conducted user interviews and caseworker shadowing, engaged stakeholders through hands-on prototyping, and delivered an intuitive, accessible interface compliant with WCAG and Section 508, refined via iterative testing and feedback.
public-sector.businessValue: The digitized SNAP application increased accessibility so more Massachusetts residents could apply for food benefits, improving engagement and satisfaction while maintaining regulatory compliance.
public-sector.targetUsers: Low-income Massachusetts residents applying for SNAP benefits, including users with language differences and varying levels of digital literacy.

staffplan.problemStatement: GoInvo lacked a lightweight, non-intrusive tool to plan, manage, and optimize team workflow and resource planning; ad hoc methods like spreadsheets and sticky notes were insufficient.
staffplan.solutionStatement: They built StaffPlan, a web-based service for quick entry of planned vs. actual time that enables bi-directional assignment and provides reports and visualizations for employees, managers, and resource managers.
staffplan.businessValue: Gave management actionable information to better run the firm and allowed leadership to focus on matching staff to assignments instead of basic organization.
staffplan.targetUsers: Employees, managers, resource managers, leadership, and project managers overseeing team plans and availability.

deliverables: Concept sketches for crowdsourcing a diagnosis
tabeeb-diagnostics.problemStatement: Rural doctors and nurses face complex cases without sufficient familiarity, experience, or equipment for confident diagnoses. Tabeeb needed healthcare design expertise to develop a telemedicine service.
tabeeb-diagnostics.solutionStatement: GoInvo defined and designed a first-generation product, iterating with clinicians and stakeholders, and provided design, engineering, and product support to ship an MVP.
tabeeb-diagnostics.businessValue: Accelerated Tabeeb from a draft business plan to a version 1 release in 8 months.
tabeeb-diagnostics.targetUsers: Primary care clinicians (doctors and nurses) in rural and remote settings who need access to expert diagnosticians.

keyMetrics: 14% of PCPs are confident in interpreting genetic test results
Validated with 50+ individuals (genetic counselors, clinicians, patients, research scientists)
User Advisory Group: 10 patients, 8 clinicians, 2 genetic counselors
deliverables: Journey map of the end-to-end carrier screening process
Industry-standard guidelines for delivering a carrier screening service
wuxi-nextcode-familycode.problemStatement: Carrier screening results are difficult for patients and many clinicians to interpret, and a shortage of genetic counselors limits clinician adoption.
wuxi-nextcode-familycode.solutionStatement: Designed a patient- and clinician-understandable carrier screening service that clearly communicates results and guides next steps, informed by interviews, a user advisory group, journey mapping, and validation.
wuxi-nextcode-familycode.businessValue: Provided a validated direction that enabled leadership to begin production and launch the first version abroad.
wuxi-nextcode-familycode.targetUsers: Patients undergoing carrier screening and clinicians offering and interpreting the test.
